Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SCC-SBE: Research Coordination Network on Leveraging Computational Social Science for Understanding Virtual Organizations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid advances in digitally-enabled communications have given rise to a new organizational form - the virtual organization. Because of their immense capacity for flexibility and their ability to draw on diverse expertise across time and space, the large-scale, cross-boundary collaborations enabled by virtual organizations have the potential to solve some of the grand challenges of today's world - those in environmental sustainability, climate change, disaster response, education, and health care. However, research on understanding and enabling virtual organizations requires the deep expertise of many disciplines including computer science, information and decision sciences, communication, management, and psychology, to name a few. Therefore an integral next step is to invest in community and infrastructure development that better fuses the "social" and the "technical" cores of this research enterprise. This need for greater socio-technical integration is at the heart of a new paradigm which we call computational social science enabled virtual organizational research (CSSeVOR).

This research coordination network will increase the interconnections between scholars across disciplines and catalyze a new community examining virtual organizations using computational and data-enabled approaches. Big data presents an enormous opportunity for organizational science, particularly the areas aimed at understanding human behavior and organizing processes. However, utilizing such data requires a fundamental transformation within the areas of science engaged in this problem domain. This project engages a core set of interdisciplinary scientists representing both the "social" and the "technical" thinking about virtual organizing, to work collaboratively to build the scientific network needed to tackle the challenges of utilizing big data in the organizational sciences, and to set up the necessary conditions for big-data enabled organizational science research to thrive. The project team will conduct workshops, research incubators, doctoral consortia, and a conference to build community and capacity for computational virtual organization research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to hold events that could build and nurture the community of researchers who work in the area of computational social science enabled virtual organizational research (CSSeVOR). Throughout the lifetime of this project we planned and implemented 3 stand­alone workshops and organized 3 events at existing conferences. Our 3 standalone events convened members from different social scientific backgrounds with computational scholars to advance work in the area of CSSeVOR. The 3 events at existing conferences were conducted at top national conferences and were designed to reach a different target audience and inspire future research in the area of CSSeVOR.

Our first major standalone workshop, the International Workshop on Network Theory: Network Science Meets the Science of Teams, took place in October 2013 in Evanston, IL. This workshop sought to catalyze a dialog among a community of thought leaders on teams and multi team systems, network theory, and computational science. The workshop was organized by the Annenberg Networks Network (ANN) at the University of Southern California, the Developing Effective Leaders, Teams and Alliances (DELTA) Lab at the Georgia Institute of Technology, the Science of Networks in Communities (SONIC) Lab, and the Northwestern Institute on Complex Systems (NICO) at Northwestern University. The workshop included presentations from 16 researchers and had multiple group events that allowed for the cross-pollination of ideas across disciplines and enabled the development of a common understanding and language.

The second standalone workshop, the Computational Social Science Summit, was hosted in May 2015 in Evanston, IL. The workshop, planned by the PIs, advisory board members, and NICO, appealed to a broad community invested in social science research, including academics, industry professionals, and government agencies. The goal of the workshop was to advance social science knowledge through the use of computational methods. Workshop highlights include multiple panels, research presentations, workshops, keynotes and a datathon. The keynote speakers represented a wide variety of cutting edge computational social scientists, including: David Ferruci (Bridgewater Associates, formerly of IBM Watson), Katy Börner (Indiana University), Sandra González Bailón (Annenberg School of Communication at the University of Pennsylvania), and Michael Macy (Cornell University).

The third stand­alone workshop, the International Workshop on Network Theory: Peer Production Networks, was hosted in October 2015 in Evanston, IL. The workshop was planned by the same committee who convened the event in 2013. The workshop brought together thought leaders engaged in research, development, management, and leadership of peer production systems and related phenomena. Specifically, participants identified central challenges, set research agendas, and facilitated collaboration opportunities to explore the mechanisms that enable the formation and performance of peer production networks. The keynote speaker was Yochai Benkler, a leading networks researcher from Harvard University. Other speakers represented a wide range in both disciplines and nationalities.

We held 3 events at existing conferences where CSSeVOR communities already convene. The first was a symposium conducted at the 2014 Society of Industrial and Organizational Psychology’s annual conference titled “Social Science and the Digital Revolution”. The symposium offered insights into how the data, tools, and methods used in social science are advanced by the advent of technology.
